items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Dan Moser, Associate Superintendent of Instruction and Human RelationsSUBJECT:Hold Public Hearing at 6:15 p.m. to Adopt Resolution Regarding Sufficiency of Textbooks and Instructional Materials per Education Code 60119In accordance with the California Education Code, a public hearing is required to comply with the Williams Settlement in order to determine Sufficiency of Textbooks & Instructional Materials.The Sufficiency of Textbooks and Instructional Materials resolution is required by Education Code Section 60119.  Each year, school districts are required to declare by resolution whether or not all students have access to sufficient instructional materials consistent with the State curricular frameworks.
items.item_text: Hold Public Hearing at 6:15 p.m. to Adopt Resolution Regarding Sufficiency of Textbooks and Instructional Materials per Education Code 60119 - Dan Moser, Associate Superintendent of Instruction and Human Relations
items.item_text_raw: 8.02 Hold Public Hearing at 6:15 p.m. to Adopt Resolution Regarding Sufficiency of Textbooks and Instructional Materials per Education Code 60119 - Dan Moser, Associate Superintendent of Instruction and Human Relations

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO: Board of TrusteesFROM: Bob Nuñez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY: Dan Moser, Associate Superintendent of Instruction and Human RelationsSUBJECT:Adopt Resolution #2008/2009-03 Regarding the Sufficiency of Textbooks and Instructional MaterialsAs a result of the Williams settlement, all students in California have the right to sufficient textbooks and instructional materials, defined as “a standards-aligned textbook or instructional materials, or both, to use in class and to take home.” EC § 60119(c)(1).School boards must make a determination, through a resolution, as to whether each pupil in each school in the district has sufficient textbooks or instructional materials, or both, that are aligned to the content standards . . . in each of the following subjects, as appropriate, that are consistent with the content and cycles of the curriculum framework adopted by the state board: [Math, Science (including laboratory science equipment in high school lab science courses), History-Social Science, English/Language Arts (including the English language development component of an adopted program), foreign language, and health]. EC § 60119(a)(1)(A).Where insufficiencies exist, the resolution must provide school-specific information regarding “the percentage of pupils who lack sufficient standards-aligned textbooks or instructional materials in each subject area and the reasons that each pupil does not have sufficient textbooks or instructional materials, or both.” EC § 60119(a)(2)(A). Finally, the governing board must “take action to ensure that each pupil has sufficient textbooks or instructional materials, or both, within two months of the beginning of the school year.”FISCAL IMPACT: To be DeterminedFUNDING SOURCE:Senate Bill 6 (Williams)State Instructional Materials AllocationDistrict Instructional Materials BudgetRECOMMENDATION:The administration recommends that the Governing Board determine a finding of sufficiency in instructional materials and supplies as specified in Resolution #2008/2009-03 and hold a public hearing with due diligence on September 19, 2008, as required by the Education Code Section 60119.
items.item_text: Adopt Resolution #2008/2009–03 Regarding the Sufficiency of Textbooks and Instructional Materials - Dan Moser, Associate Superintendent of Instruction and Human Relations
items.item_text_raw: 8.03 Adopt Resolution #2008/2009–03 Regarding the Sufficiency of Textbooks and Instructional Materials - Dan Moser, Associate Superintendent of Instruction and Human Relations

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business ServicesSUBJECT:Hold Public Hearing at 6:20 p.m. to Adopt Gann Spending Limit per Education Code Sections 42123 and 1629In accordance with the California Education Code, a public hearing is to be held prior to the adoption of Resolution #2008/2009-04 Gann Spending Limit.The Gann amendment limits the growth rate of income for state and local governments including school districts.  Each year, school districts and other agencies affected by the Amendment must calculate their Appropriations Limit for the coming year.  There is no direct relationship between the figures, which appear in the calculations of the Gann Limitation and other 2008/2009 budget data since the calculation deals exclusively with proceeds of taxes.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business ServicesJulie Kasberger, Director of General ServicesSUBJECT:Responses to Santa Clara County Civil Grand Jury Report - Inventory Practices Inadequate in Santa Clara County School DistrictsBelow are responses to Findings and Recommendations to the Civil Grand Jury Report, “Inventory Practices Inadequate in Santa Clara County School Districts” dated June 4, 2008, from the East Side Union High School District.  The District’s responses are based upon what was stated in the report and not on knowledge or information this District has about any other school district in the county or the Santa Clara County Office of Education.The District does take the stewardship of the public’s assets seriously and does meet the requirements of the State of California’s laws and regulations in relation to maintaining those assets over their useful life.  We strive to improve the protection and maintenance of those public assets continuously.  We desire absolute protection of those assets however resources to accomplish that have not been made available to public education in California. Not withstanding the current State economic problems a reliable funding base for public education has not been available since the fallout of Proposition 13 in 1978.SANTA CLARA COUNTYCIVIL GRAND JURY REPORTResponses to Findings and Recommendations to “Inventory Practices Inadequate in Santa Clara County School Districts”.Finding 1:East Side Union High School District agrees that the FCMAT reports may help other school districts address deficiencies.Recommendation 1:Implemented:  East Side Union High School District has reviewed the FCMAT reports and notes that improvements can be made in the district’s annual inventory process, policy and administrative regulations.Finding 2:East Side Union High School District agrees that based on the report most school districts do not follow all appropriate state/federal guidelines with respect to frequency and method by which equipment must be inventoried.Recommendation 2a:Partially Implemented:  East Side Union High School District has reviewed relevant law and guidelines and policies concerning frequency and method of inventories.  All District Business Policies are scheduled to be reviewed and updated by December 2008 at which time the inventory policy will be revised.  Recommendation 2b:This recommendation will not be implemented because it is vague and not reasonable.  School districts in California are required to have an annual independent audit by a qualified accounting firm.   Among the test that those independent firms do is for internal controls and asset inventories which include compliance with California Codes and the California School Accounting Manual.  What East Side Union High School District intends to do is to specify that those reviews are done annually during the independent audit and included in the Financial Statements.Finding 3:East Side Union High School District agrees that based on the reports some school districts in the county do not follow state law with respect to minimum value of equipment that must be inventoried.Recommendation 3:Implemented:  East Side Union High School District has reviewed relevant law and guidelines and policies concerning minimum value of equipment that must be inventoried and does comply with the requirements.Finding 4:East Side Union High School District agrees that based on the reports some school districts in the county do not hold employees accountable for lost property and equipment.Recommendation 4:This is not yet implemented but the area of holding employees accountable for lost property or equipment is one area that will be addressed in the policy updates mentioned in the response to Recommendation 2a.  Current policy does identify site property managers however the documentation process for missing equipment contained on inventory listings does need further clarification.  Finding 5:East Side Union High School District agrees that based on the reports some school boards in the county are not advised of results of inventories.Recommendation 5:This recommendation has not yet been implemented but will be within the timeline identified in Recommendation 2a also pertinent to this recommendation are the comments made in response to Recommendation 2b.  The process developed for policy revision will include notification to the Board of Education of material or cumulative losses in inventory.  Depreciation is a form of loss in inventory although it is gradual loss that would be recorded in the assets of the district as an accounting entry and not a specific report to the Board.Finding 6:East Side Union High School District agrees that based on the reports some school districts in the county do not have appropriate board policies regarding acquisition, inventory and disposition of property and equipment.Recommendation 6:East Side Union High School District has reviewed and will enact updated board policies regarding acquisition, inventory and disposition of property and equipment where appropriate on the schedule mentioned in response to Recommendation 2a.Finding 7:East Side Union High School District agrees that based on the reports some school districts in the county do not have appropriate administrative regulation regarding acquisition, inventory and disposition of property and equipment.Recommendation 7:East Side Union High School District will make appropriate revisions to administrative regulation regarding acquisition, inventory and disposition of property and equipment that may be needed after the updating of the board policies schedule for not later than December 2008.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and FacilitiesJohn Fox, CCOC DirectorGerri Forte, Director of Career ServicesSUBJECT:Alternative Career Technical Training (ACTT) High SchoolOverview:The ESUHSD is developing additional educational opportunities for students, and we are proud to announce the following new program designed for sophomore students:  Alternative Career Technical Training High School.  This program will be housed at the Central County Occupational Center (CCOC) operated by MetroEd located at 760 Hillsdale Avenue, San Jose, CA 95136.  Selected sophomore students from the ESUHSD will be able to participate in this pilot program.  The program will consist of an academic core (English, Mathematics, and Social Science) taught in the morning and a three-hour block of a Career and Technical Education (CTE) program taught in the afternoon.  Students will be able to select from the following:  Air Conditioning and Refrigeration, Animation, Brakes & Alignment, Computer Aided Drafting, Graphic Design, Interior Design, and Managerial Accounting.  Transportation to and from the CCOC facility will be provided by MetroEd at no cost to the student.  Free and reduced price lunches will also be provided.  Students accepted into the program will receive personalized attention from the instructor and counseling services with the goal of high school graduation accompanied with CTE certification as the end result.  Students will receive ESUHSD Student Identification Cards that will allow them to participate in extracurricular activities (games, dances, etc.) that all ESUHSD students have access to.Accomplishments:Throughout the ESUHSD, we have identified and/or developed integrated career programs in the form of academies or magnet programs, identified and trained teacher teams, and continued with the integration of instruction through incorporation of core subject standards and relevancy activities.  We have also refined our Quality Criteria and Standards for Career-Technical Education programs, established career exploration and assessment activities, developed transition sequences to post secondary study, implemented skill certification programs, and developed a support academy for special education students.Our integrated career paths and academies are aligned with state career incentives.  These include increasing access for special population students, implementing activities to ensure that students are developing employability skills, and increasing work-based learning opportunities for studentsThis new program is in alignment with the CTE accomplishments of the East Side Union High School District.FISCAL IMPACT:$80,000 - $100,000FUNDING SOURCE:General Fund for the Academic Core Teacher SalaryRECOMMENDATION:This is for the Boards review.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business ServicesSUBJECT:Approve Unaudited Actuals for 2007-2008The 2008-2009 Budget for East Side Union High School District, adopted June 26, 2008 included the Unrestricted General Fund ending fund balance for 2007/08, $14,701,179 including General Reserves of $7,543,406.  Upon closing the booked accounts including actual incomes and expenditures recorded and revised as necessary.  The ending fund balance improved to $16,176,674 including General Reserves of $7,089,332.  The beginning fund balance of $10,598,901 declined by $1,069,707 which is a 10 percent decline in the Unrestricted General Fund balance.  In the 2008-2009 Budget the multi-year projections indicated a continued pattern of deficit spending (expenditures in excess of annual income) for the two subsequent fiscal years to a point that the District would realize a negative fund balance in the 2010-2011 fiscal year.  A plan to address this trend of deficit spending will need to be addressed for the District’s First Interim Financial Report.The deadline for providing the Unaudited Actual Report to the Santa Clara County Office of Education is September 15, 2008.The Unaudited Ending Balance will be audited and revised, as necessary, through the external fiscal Audit process scheduled to be completed in December, 2008 and submitted to the Board in January, 2009.FISCAL IMPACT:Improvement in Beginning Fund Balance for 2008-2009.FUNDING SOURCE:Not ApplicableRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Unaudited Actuals for 2007-2008

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business ServicesSUBJECT:Adopt Resolution #2008/2009-07 to Issue Tax and Revenue Anticipation Notes for Fiscal Year 2008/09Tax Revenue and Anticipation Notes (TRANs) are short-term debt instruments issued by school districts and other public agencies to creat additional cash reserves.  In East Side, this cash reserve acts as a cushion to the general fund in the event that the District experiences temporary cash flow needs.  These cash flow needs may occur as a result of the timing mismatch between the receipt of revenues and the payments to staff and vendors. Through participation in this type of financing, the District will issue a one-year tax-exempt note.  The proceeds from the sale of this note, when not needed for cash flow, will be placed in a special interest bearing fund at the County which will result in a positive spread between the borrowing ratae and the investment return on the TRANs proceeds.The District issued $11 million in 2003/04, $10.5 million in 2004/05, $8.5 million in 2005/06 and $14 million in 2006/07, $11 million in 2007/08.  The amount of the issuance for this coming year (2008/09) will be known until a cash flow analysis is completed in September 2008, when more of the variables are known.  However, we estimate the TRANs will not exceed $15 million with an estimated net positive interest accrual after all expenses of approximately 50,000.FISCAL IMPACT:50,000.00FUNDING SOURCE:General FundRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended the Board of Trustees Adopt Resolution #2008/2009-07 authorizing the issuance of 2008/09 Tax and Revenue Anticipation Notes (TRANs)

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTBOARD RESOLUTION NO. 2008/2009-08 To Endorse and Support Measure WBerryessa Union School District on the November 4, 2008 BallotWHEREAS, Berryessa Union School District has not been funded adequately by the State to provide a quality educational program, and the District is committed to maintaining a balanced budget; andWHEREAS, Berryessa Union School District is facing severe budget cuts due to State reductions in education funding and is 30th of 32 districts in our County in funding; andWHEREAS, Berryessa Union School District has already cut district administration by 40%, eliminated teaching positions, reduced counseling, reduced library hours, reduced after school tutoring, reduced support for students learning English – and even with these cuts, Berryessa schools face a $1.3 million deficit.  WHEREAS, the Berryessa Union School District has exhausted all feasible means of generating funds and without a parcel tax the District would be forced to significantly reduce basic educational services with an direct impact on the quality of instruction available to local students; andWHEREAS, the Berryessa Union School District Board of Education has determined, in its best judgment, that in order to maintain quality education in Berryessa, stable locally-controlled revenue from a parcel tax is necessary; andWHEREAS, the Berryessa Union School District Board of Education voted to place Measure W on the ballot to retain qualified teachers and avoid layoffs, maintain reading and math specialists, keep school libraries open, provide hands-on science instruction, update and expand classroom technology, and fund programs that enhance student achievement; andWHEREAS, Measure W will cost homeowners $79 per year and last five years with an exemption available for seniors to ensure this measure is not a burden to those living on fixed incomes; andWHEREAS, every penny raised by Measure W will stay in Berryessa to benefit our children and  No money can be taken by the State or used for administrator salaries; andWHEREAS, an independent citizens’ oversight committee and annual audits will ensure Measure W funds are spent properly; andWHEREAS, good schools protect property values, which is more important now than ever;NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED THAT THE EAST SIDE HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT LENDS ITS OFFICIAL ENDORSMENT AND SUPPORT TO MEASURE W FOR THE BERRYESSA UNION SCHOOL DISTRICT.ADOPTED, SIGNED and APPROVED by the East Side Union High School District Board of Trustees on September 18, 2008, by the following vote: AYES:  ___________  NOES:  ___________	  ABSTENTIONS:  ___________	 ABSENT:  ___________	 Signed by: _________________________________President – Board of TrusteesEast Side Union High School DistrictAttested to: _________________________________ Clerk/Secretary – Board of TrusteesEast Side Union High School District

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business ServicesJil Kauffman, Coordinator of Risk ManagementOn behalf of: Vivian Nguyen, ASB President, Andrew Hill High SchoolMichelle Nguyen, Vice President, Andrew Hill High SchoolVicky Tran, ASB President of Special Events, Andrew Hill High SchoolTyna Huynh, ASB Treasurer/President of Finance and Records, Andrew Hill High SchoolSUBJECT:Request for One-Time Waiver of Board Policy 5142.1 to allow for a Fireworks Display at Andrew Hill High School on October 24, 2008Students of Andrew Hill High School are requesting that the use of fireworks/pyrotechnic display be approved on a one-time basis. This display is for homecoming pre-game celebration.Board Policy 5142.1 prohibits the following at the school sites and on District facilities: (1) Open fires including bonfires of any type; (2) Pyrotechnics of any type; and (3) Explosive devices such as firecrackers. Various schools have requested a one-time waiver of Board Policy 5142.1 to allow for the planned fireworks/pyrotechnics display for homecoming celebrations.Administration recommends Board approval of the one-time waiver on the following conditions:This is a one-time waiver only.The school and the fireworks and pyrotechnics company provider shall provide copies of all necessary, required and appropriate governmental permits, licenses and approvals no later than one business day before the planned event.The school and the fireworks and pyrotechnics company provider shall provide proof of adequate liability insurance coverage for the event, including, but not limited to, an endorsement naming the District as an additional insured to be determined by Administration and to be provided at least one business day before the planned event.The fireworks/pyrotechnics displays shall be staged in a safe area.The school shall obtain adequate security and public fire safety personnel and equipment on site during the scheduled event.No other fireworks of any kind shall be allowed on the school campus.The pyrotechnic companies shall be responsible for any damage to the campus, including, but not  limited to, the newly-renovated  athletic and activities fields.FISCAL IMPACT:Not ApplicableFUNDING SOURCE:Not ApplicableRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the one-time waiver of Board Policy 5142.1 to allow for a fireworks display at Andrew Hill High School, which will be subject to the conditions as stated above and approval from the San Jose Fire Marshall.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business ServicesJil Kauffman, Coordinator of Risk ManagementOn behalf of:Joey Flores, ASB President, Yerba Buena High SchoolHenry Ngo, ASB President of Special Events, Yerba Buena High SchoolSUBJECT:Request for One-Time Waiver of Board Policy 5142.1 to allow for a Fireworks Display at Yerba Buena High School on November 7, 2008Students of Yerba Buena High School are requesting that the use of fireworks/pyrotechnic display be approved on a one-time basis. This display is for homecoming pre-game celebration.Board Policy 5142.1 prohibits the following at the school sites and on District facilities: (1) Open fires including bonfires of any type; (2) Pyrotechnics of any type; and (3) Explosive devices such as firecrackers. Various schools have requested a one-time waiver of Board Policy 5142.1 to allow for the planned fireworks/pyrotechnics display for homecoming celebrations.Administration recommends Board approval of the one-time waiver on the following conditions:This is a one-time waiver only.The school and the fireworks and pyrotechnics company provider shall provide copies of all necessary, required and appropriate governmental permits, licenses and approvals no later than one business day before the planned event.The school and the fireworks and pyrotechnics company provider shall provide proof of adequate liability insurance coverage for the event, including, but not limited to, an endorsement naming the District as an additional insured to be determined by Administration and to be provided at least one business day before the planned event.The fireworks/pyrotechnics displays shall be staged in a safe area.The school shall obtain adequate security and public fire safety personnel and equipment on site during the scheduled event.No other fireworks of any kind shall be allowed on the school campus.The pyrotechnic companies shall be responsible for any damage to the campus, including, but not  limited to, the newly-renovated  athletic and activities fields.FISCAL IMPACT:Not ApplicableFUNDING SOURCE:Not ApplicableRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the one-time waiver of Board Policy 5142.1 to allow for a fireworks display at Yerba Buena High School, which will be subject to the conditions as stated above and approval from the San Jose Fire Marshall.
items.item_text: Request for One-Time Waiver of Board Policy 5142.1 to allow for a Fireworks Display at Yerba Buena High School - Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business Services
items.item_text_raw: 8.14 Request for One-Time Waiver of Board Policy 5142.1 to allow for a Fireworks Display at Yerba Buena High School - Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business Services

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business ServicesSUBJECT:Program Management Services Agreement with The Seville Group, Inc. MeasureE General Obligation School Facilities Bond ProgramThe District’s Measure G Bond program has been managed since the year 2003 by the Seville Group, Inc. (“SGI”).   The June 15, 2008 Facilities Program Management Review by Total School Solutions (specifically page 3 (1st bullet), page 27 (second paragraph) and page 28 (under Program Manager) states that a combination of district staff resources and contracted Program Management services has been an effective model under Measure G projects.  At the Board meeting in June the Board authorized the District staff to develop an agreement with the Seville Group, Inc. for Program Management Services anticipated for Measure E projects.  Some of the specifics of the agreement are:TERM:3 Years with extension at discretion of DistrictFEE:5% of project costs over term of contract excluding real property acquisitionsSCOPE:Schedule, coordinate, monitor work of Master Plan Architects, Project Architects, Construction Managers, Programming, full design, construction documents, State Allocation Board applications, other State agency Applications and documentsTERMINATION:Cause - 30 days after written notice of either partyConvenience - 30 days after written notice by DistrictDistrict covers demobilization costFISCAL IMPACT:To be determined from Bond FundRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees award the contract for Measure E program management services with the Seville Group, Inc.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business ServicesSUBJECT:Award Contract for Demographic ServicesIn accordance with California Government Code 53060 and in the search for information to best utilize the District’s assets, the District issued a formal Request for Qualification (RFQ) for Demography Services. The District advertised in a local newspaper for “Demographic Services” and sent RFQ forms to known companies. After applying the District's criteria and a selection matrix it was concluded that Davis Demographies & Planning, Inc., will meet the needs of the District for demographic services.  We are recommending the demographic services contract be awarded to Davis Demographics & Planning, Inc.FISCAL IMPACT:Not to exceed $75,000FUNDING SOURCE:General Fund & Capitol FacilitiesRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended the Board of Trustees award the contract for demographic services to Davis Demographics and Planning, Inc.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Dan Moser, Associate Superintendent of Instruction and Human RelationsSUBJECT:Approve the change in Governance and Operations of KIPP San Jose Collegiate from KIPP Hearwood Academy to KIPP: Bay Area SchoolsBACKGROUNDOn December 13, 2007, the ESUHSD Board of Trustees formally approved the charter petition for KIPP San Jose Collegiate.  The petition listed KIPP Bay Area Schools as the nonprofit public benefit corporation as charter holder for KIPP San Jose Collegiate with KIPP Heartwood Academy in charge of operations and governance of the new charter.  KIPP Bay Area Schools has requested that the original petition be modified to list KIPP Bay Ares schools as the entity directly responsible for operations and governance of KIPP San Jose Collegiate.  The intent is to streamline the governance and management systems across all Bay Areas KIPP schools to create efficiencies, achieve greater economies of scale and access additional resources.  The request by KIPP Bay Area Schools is a non-substantial change to the original petition and is viewed as beneficial to the long term success of KIPP San Jose Collegiate.  FISCAL IMPACT:NoneFUNDING SOURCE:Not ApplicableRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the change in governance and operations of KIPP San Jose Collegiate from KIPP Heartwood Academy to KIPP: Bay Area Schools.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob Nuñez, SuperintendentSUBJECT:Approve Amendment to MetroED Joint Powers Agreement (JPA) regarding Temporary Second Alternate Board Member ProcessThe MetroED Board at their meeting of June 11, 2008, unanimously approved a new clause in the Joint Powers Agreement (JPA) with the six JPA participating districts.  The new clause doe not amend any of the existing JPA language.  The amendment is as follows:11.3.1 Temporary Second AlternateIn the event both a Participating District's Education District Governing board member and alternate are unable to attend and Education District Governing Board meeting, the Participating District Board President may appoint a temporary second alternate Board Member  to attend the meeting.  The Participating District Superintendent shall inform the Education District Superintendent in writing of the appointment in advance of the attendance of a temporary alternate at a specified Board meeting.  This written notification shall be appended to the official minutes of the Education District Governing Board meeting at which the temporary alternate participates.In order to amend the Joint Powers Agreement, all six participating districts must be in agreement.  MetroED is not requesting the six participating districts to approve the amendment, but to confirm that the Board of the six districts will approve the amendment.  Upon concurrence of all six districts, MetroED will provide each participating district with an amended JPA for Board approval.FISCAL IMPACT:NoneFUNDING SOURCE:NoneRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the amended language in section 11.3.1 as identified above.

items.item_details: TEAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob Nuñez, SuperintendentSUBJECT:California School Boards Association (CSBA) Candidate Nomination for Directors-at-Large:  Asian/Pacific Islander and HispanicThe California School Boards Association (CSBA) is currently accepting nominations for Directors-at-Large:  Asian/Pacific Islander and Hispanic.  The election will take place at CSBA's Delegate Assembly meeting in San Diego on December 3-4, 2008.   Nominations for Directors-at-Large must be made by a Board Member from a CSBA member district or county office of education.  Directors-at-Large serve a two-year term and take office immediately upon the close of the Association's Annual Education Conference.  The Board is requested to submit nominations to CSBA for Directors-at-Large:  Asian/Pacific Islander and Hispanic.FISCAL IMPACT:NoneFUNDING SOURCE:NoneRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees submit nominations to CSBA for Directors-at-Large:  Asian/Pacific Islander and Hispanic.
